items.title: DUMB - A Unified Media Solution
items.text:
DUMB is an all-in-one media management and streaming solution that integrates multiple services into a single Docker image for streamlined deployment. Automate finding, downloading, and organizing media content using Debrid Services, Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, Seerr, and more.

Deployment Guide

items.title: Quick Start
items.text: Get DUMB up and running in minutes with our streamlined deployment process. Choose from Docker, Portainer, Unraid, or other platforms.

items.title: Unified Platform
items.text: All your favorite media services in one container. Plex, Jellyfin, Emby, Sonarr, Radarr, and more‚Äîpre-configured and ready to use.

items.title: Automated Workflows
items.text: Connect your Debrid services, Trakt lists, and Plex Discover watchlists. DUMB handles the rest‚Äîfrom discovery to streaming.

items.title: What's Included
items.text:
DUMB integrates a comprehensive ecosystem of media management tools:

Media Servers: Plex Media Server, Jellyfin, Emby Orchestrators: Riven, CLI Debrid, Plex Debrid, Decypharr, NzbDAV Automation: Sonarr, Radarr, Lidarr, Prowlarr, Whisparr Storage & Caching: Zurg, rclone, Zilean Database: PostgreSQL, pgAdmin 4

All services work together seamlessly with Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, Seerr, and more to streamline media discovery and access.

Ready to get started? Check out the Deployment Guide or explore the Features and Services documentation.

items.title: About DUMB (Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge)
items.text: Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) is an all-in-one, containerized platform for managing and automating media workflows using premium debrid services like Real-Debrid. Whether you're looking to automate downloads, organize libraries, mount remote content, or just reduce manual steps ‚Äî DUMB aims to unify it all into a seamless experience.

items.title: Mission
items.text:
DUMB was created with a single goal:

Bridge the gap between cloud-based debrid services and traditional media server ecosystems like Plex, Jellyfin, and Emby ‚Äî with maximum automation and minimal configuration.

By directly integrating the media server itself (e.g. Plex) within the DUMB container, the platform overcomes long-standing issues like broken bind mount propagation, sync delays, and external scan conflicts common in multi-container setups.

items.title: What Makes DUMB Unique?
items.text:
Unlike other solutions that focus on one piece of the puzzle, DUMB integrates every step of the media pipeline:

  • Embedded Media Servers ‚Äî Plex, Jellyfin, and Emby run inside the same container, ensuring seamless access to mounted content and full internal control
  • Service Coordination ‚Äî via the internal DUMB API and real-time config management
  • Automated Acquisition ‚Äî with core services for discovery and Zurg and/or rclone for debrid content fetching
  • Cloud Storage Mounting ‚Äî through rclone mounts direct to debrid (e.g., Real-Debrid WebDAV) or utilizing Zurg's WebDAV
  • Library Management ‚Äî using symlinks, metadata enrichment, and optional server updates
  • Metadata Caching ‚Äî with Zilean to reduce latency and boost scraping efficiency
  • Visual Control ‚Äî via the DUMB Frontend for live logs, settings, and monitoring

All services are configured through a centralized file (dumb_config.json) and can be dynamically updated at runtime via the DUMB Frontend.

items.title: Architecture at a Glance
items.text:
DUMB is built using a modular, microservices architecture, with the following components:

Service Description DUMB API Core controller and coordination hub DUMB Frontend Graphical interface for managing services, configs, and logs Plex Media Server First-class embedded media server for direct playback of collected content Riven Content search, acquisition, and integration with platforms like Plex, Trakt, Seerr, etc CLI Debrid Content search, acquisition, and integration with platforms like Plex, Trakt, Seerr, etc Decypharr Content search, acquisition, and integration with platforms like Plex, Trakt, Seerr, etc Zurg Handles Real-Debrid content interaction, file repair, and directory structuring rclone Mounts cloud storage into the local container for access by your media server Zilean Caches metadata and file hash lookups for performance PostgreSQL / pgAdmin Internal databases and optional management UI

You can explore how these services connect in the Services Overview page.

items.title: Community-Driven Development
items.text:
DUMB is fully open-source and community-powered. While development is led by a single maintainer, contributions of all kinds are welcome ‚Äî not just code!

You can help by:

  • ‚≠ê Starring the GitHub repo
  • Boosting or participating in the Discord community
  • Submitting feedback, bug reports, or pull requests
  • Helping others with questions or documentation improvements
  • Sponsoring the Dev through GitHub Sponsors

See the Contributing Guide for more details.

items.title: Contributing to DUMB
items.text:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB)!

We welcome all forms of contributions ‚Äî not just code.

DUMB is an open-source, community-driven project.

Whether you're a developer, power user, or just someone passionate about improving media automation, your help is always appreciated!

Thank you for helping make DUMB better for everyone!

items.title: ‚Äç Development Contributions
items.text: Want to help develop new features, fix bugs, or improve performance?

items.title: Recommended Setup
items.text:
The easiest way to contribute code is through the DUMB Dev Container, which includes all the required tools:

  • Based on: iampuid0/dumb:latest
  • Python with Black autoformatter
  • Port forwarding for common services
  • Preconfigured workspace mounts

You can find the devcontainer setup file in the repo.

items.title: How to Get Started
items.text:
1. Fork the DUMB repository
  2. Clone your fork locally
  3. Open in VS Code using Dev Containers
  4. Make your changes, format with black, and submit a pull request

If you‚Äôre not using VS Code or Dev Containers, you can also run the project via Docker with the same mounts shown in the devcontainer.json.

items.title: Non-Code Contributions
items.text: Even if you don't write code, there are plenty of ways to help!

items.title: Star the Repo
items.text: A quick way to show support is by starring the project on GitHub: github.com/I-am-PUID-0/DUMB

items.title: Join the Community
items.text:
• Ask questions or help others in the DUMB Discord server
  • Boost the server if you find it helpful
  • Share your setups and improvements

items.title: Help with Documentation
items.text:
• Found a typo or confusing section in the docs? Open an issue or pull request.
  • Suggestions and feedback on existing documentation are always welcome.

items.title: Monetary Contributions?
items.text: • Sponsor the Dev through GitHub Sponsors

items.title: Roadmap & Feedback
items.text:
If you have ideas, feature requests, or feedback:

  • Create a GitHub Issue

  • Discuss in the community before starting larger PRs

items.title: DUMB API
items.text:
DUMB includes a built-in REST API and WebSocket server to allow programmatic control of services, logging, and system state.

The API is enabled and configured using the dumb_config.json under the dumb.api_service section. For example:

"api_service": {
  "enabled": true,
  "process_name": "DUMB API",
  "log_level": "INFO",
  "host": "127.0.0.1",
  "port": 8000
}

items.title: Features
items.text:
• Health checks
  • Process management (start, stop, restart services)
  • Real-time log streaming via WebSocket
  • Configuration viewing and updates (in-memory and persistent)
  • Environment state inspection

items.title: Common Endpoints
items.text: Method Path Description GET /health Container health check GET /process/processes List all services in dumb_config.json GET /process Get a specific service by process_name POST /process/start-service Start a specific service POST /process/stop-service Stop a specific service POST /process/restart-service Restart a specific service GET /process/service-status Get the current status of a service POST /process/start-core-service Start core services + dependencies GET /logs Read service log chunks WS /ws/logs Real-time log streaming

items.title: Directory Structure
items.text:
The DUMB API is split into the following modules:

File Purpose api_service.py Initializes and launches the FastAPI app api_state.py Tracks and updates service runtime state connection_manager.py Manages WebSocket client connections config.py Endpoints for working with dumb_config.json and service configs health.py Health check endpoint for validating API status logs.py REST endpoint for reading historical logs websocket_logs.py WebSocket server for streaming real-time logs to frontend process.py Service control for backend processes (start, stop, restart)

items.title: API Documentation
items.text:
DUMB provides built-in API documentation through two convenient endpoints:

  • FastAPI Swagger UI Accessible at: http://<host>:<port>/docs This interface allows for interactive testing and exploring of all available REST endpoints.

  • Scalar (ReDoc-style) Docs Accessible at: http://<host>:<port>/scalar A clean, read-only view of the full OpenAPI schema for the DUMB API.

These are helpful for development, debugging, and integrating external systems with DUMB.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
Click on any of the modules in the sidebar to explore endpoint structure, usage examples, and development guidelines for extending the DUMB API:

  • Health Check
  • Logs
  • Process Management
  • Configuration
  • WebSocket Logs

items.title: Configuration API
items.text: The Configuration API is responsible for exposing endpoints that manage and manipulate DUMB's configuration settings (dumb_config.json). These endpoints provide tools for loading, updating, saving, and validating configuration data for all DUMB services.

items.title: Module: config.py
items.text: Located in: api/routers/config.py

items.title: GET /config
items.text:
Description: Returns the currently loaded in-memory configuration. You can optionally pass process_name to fetch a single service block.

Usage Example: 

curl http://localhost:8000/config

items.title: POST /config
items.text:
Description: Updates config in memory. When process_name is provided, it updates only that service block and can optionally persist to disk. Without process_name, it performs a global update.

Request Body: 

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend",
  "updates": {
    "log_level": "DEBUG"
  },
  "persist": true
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"process_name":"Riven Backend","updates":{"log_level":"DEBUG"},"persist":true}'

items.title: GET /config/schema
items.text:
Description: Returns the JSON schema used for config validation.

Usage Example: 

curl http://localhost:8000/config/schema

items.title: POST /config/process-config/schema
items.text:
Description: Returns the config schema subtree for a specific process_name.

Request Body: 

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend"
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config/process-config/schema \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"process_name":"Riven Backend"}'

items.title: POST /config/service-config
items.text:
Description: Reads or updates a service-specific config file (JSON/YAML/CONF/Python/XML). If updates is omitted, the raw config is returned.

Request Body: 

{
  "service_name": "Zurg w/ RealDebrid",
  "updates": ""
}

Usage Example: 

curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/config/service-config \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"service_name":"Zurg w/ RealDebrid"}'

items.title: GET /config/service-ui
items.text: Description: Returns a list of enabled services with UI ports and writes a Traefik dynamic config file.

items.title: GET /config/onboarding-status
items.text: Description: Returns whether onboarding is required.

items.title: POST /config/onboarding-completed
items.text: Description: Marks onboarding as complete.

items.title: POST /config/reset-onboarding
items.text:
Description: Resets onboarding to incomplete.

Developer Notes

  • The config is held in memory for fast access and allows the user to experiment or preview changes before committing them to file.
  • Validation uses internal DUMB schema checks to ensure required keys and structure.
  • Routes include error handling for malformed config data.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text:
• Services Overview
  • Logs

items.title: Health Check API
items.text: The Health Check API provides a simple mechanism to verify that the DUMB container and core services are operational.

items.title: GET /health
items.text: Returns a JSON response indicating whether the container is healthy.

items.title: Response
items.text:
{
  "status": "healthy"
}

If the check fails, the status will be "unhealthy" and include diagnostic output.

Use Cases

  • Used by orchestrators or monitoring tools to confirm container availability.
  • Use in load balancers or uptime monitoring dashboards.

items.title: Implementation
items.text:
This route executes a background health check script in the container: 

/healthcheck.py
It runs within the same virtual environment as DUMB and ensures all critical files, paths, and subprocesses are functional.

items.title: Related
items.text:
• API Overview
  • Process Management

items.title: Logs API
items.text: The Logs API allows clients to retrieve recent logs captured by DUMB and served through the API.

items.title: Endpoint
items.text: GET /logs

items.title: Query Parameters
items.text: Parameter Type Description process_name string Required process name (e.g., Riven Backend, Zurg w/ RealDebrid). cursor int Last byte offset returned by the API (omit for first request). tail_bytes int Initial bytes to read from the end when no cursor (default: 131072).

items.title: Example Request
items.text:
GET /logs?process_name=Riven%20Backend

This request fetches the latest log chunk for the specified service.

items.title: Response Format
items.text:
Returns a JSON object containing the log chunk and cursor:

{
  "process_name": "Riven Backend",
  "cursor": 123456,
  "chunk": "Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started\n",
  "reset": true,
  "log": "Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started\n"
}

Important Notes

  • When reset is true, clients should replace their log buffer with chunk.
  • On incremental requests, pass the returned cursor to get only new bytes.

items.title: Related
items.text:
• Real-Time WebSocket Logs for live streaming logs.
  • Process Management for interacting with services whose logs may be captured here.

items.title: Process Management API
items.text: The Process Management endpoints handle launching, stopping, restarting, and tracking subprocesses managed by DUMB.

items.title: GET /process/processes
items.text: Returns all configured processes, including enabled status, version, repo URL, and sponsorship URL.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "processes": [
    {
      "name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
      "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
      "enabled": true,
      "config": { "enabled": true, "...": "..." },
      "version": "1.65.1",
      "key": "rclone",
      "config_key": "rclone",
      "repo_url": "https://rclone.org",
      "sponsorship_url": "https://rclone.org/sponsor/"
    }
  ]
}

items.title: GET /process
items.text: Fetch details about a specific process.

items.title: Required Query Parameter:
items.text: • process_name (string)

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
  "config": { "enabled": true, "...": "..." },
  "version": "1.65.1",
  "config_key": "rclone"
}

items.title: POST /process/start-service
items.text: Starts a specific process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "status": "Service started successfully",
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: POST /process/stop-service
items.text: Stops a running process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: POST /process/restart-service
items.text: Restarts a running process.

items.title: Request Body:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid"
}

items.title: GET /process/service-status
items.text: Gets the current status of a process.

items.title: Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "process_name": "rclone w/ RealDebrid",
  "status": "running"
}

items.title: POST /process/start-core-service
items.text:
Starts one or more core services and all required dependencies. This is used during onboarding.

The core_services field can be a single object or an array. The name can be the config key (e.g., riven_backend) or a display name (e.g., Riven).

items.title: Request Body Examples:
Example Response:
items.text:
{
  "results": [
    {"service": "riven_backend", "status": "started"},
    {"service": "decypharr", "status": "started"}
  ],
  "errors": []
}

Notes

  • Dependencies like Zurg or rclone are created using templates and attached to the calling core service.
  • Optional services such as pgadmin or zilean are started only if included.
  • debrid_key is injected into Zurg or Decypharr as needed.
  • service_options can override config values such as log_level, port, or enabled.
  • Any startup errors appear in the errors list.

items.title: GET /process/core-services
items.text: Returns the available core services, their dependencies, and default service options (used by onboarding).

items.title: GET /process/optional-services
items.text:
Returns optional services. You can pass core_service and optional_services query params to tailor the list.

Important Notes

  • All process names are matched against the entries defined in dumb_config.json.
  • Most process commands are defined as arrays and are managed with subprocess handling inside Python.

items.title: Related Files
items.text:
• process.py
  • Configuration

items.title: WebSocket Logs API
items.text: The WebSocket Logs API provides a real-time streaming interface for receiving logs from all DUMB-managed subprocesses. It is primarily used by the DUMB Frontend to power the live log viewer.

items.title: WebSocket Endpoint
items.text:
/ws/logs

Connect to this endpoint using a WebSocket client (e.g., browser or Python client) to receive log lines as plain text.

items.title: Message Format
items.text:
Each log entry is sent as a plain text line formatted by DUMB‚Äôs logger, for example:

Apr 12, 2025 10:04:01 - INFO - Riven Backend started

Filtering Logs (Client-side)

The server pushes all logs to connected clients. It is up to the client to filter based on:

  • Process Name
  • Log Level
  • Search Term

The DUMB Frontend implements dropdowns and search bars for this purpose.

Connection Behavior

  • The server broadcasts logs to all connected WebSocket clients.
  • If the connection is dropped, reconnect using /ws/logs.
  • Log history is not buffered, so missed logs are not resent on reconnect.
  • Sending {"type":"ping"} will return pong.

items.title: Example (Python Client)
items.text:
import websockets
import asyncio
import json

async def consume_logs():
    uri = "ws://localhost:8000/ws/logs"
    async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket:
        async for message in websocket:
            print(message)

asyncio.run(consume_logs())

  • Logs API for historical log file access

items.title: Deployment Overview
items.text:
DUMB can be deployed across a variety of platforms and environments. Whether you're using Docker, Portainer, Unraid, WSL2, or other systems like TrueNAS, Synology, or QNAP, this section will guide you through the available options to get DUMB up and running.

All deployment methods provide access to the same integrated services and configurations, with slight differences in how the container is started and managed.

Platform-Specific Instructions

Select your platform from the left navigation to view detailed, platform-specific deployment instructions. Each platform guide includes step-by-step setup instructions tailored to your environment.

items.title: System Requirements
items.text:
• Docker or Docker-compatible environment
  • Linux system (WSL on Windows when using rshared)
  • Minimum 2 vCPU, 2GB RAM, SSD recommended

Docker Desktop

Docker Desktop CANNOT be used to run DUMB when using rshared mount propagation.

Docker Desktop does not support the mount propagation required for rclone mounts.

See the deployment options to run DUMB on Windows through WSL2.

items.title: Required Credentials
items.text:
Service Required Info Debrid API Key (Real-Debrid) GitHub Token (if using the sponsored Zurg repo)

See Configuration ‚Üí Integration Tokens

items.title: Required Directories
items.text:
You'll need to bind mount the following volumes when running the container:

Container Mount Path Description /config Location for configuration files /log Location for logs /zurg/RD Location for Zurg RealDebrid active configuration /riven/backend/data Location for Riven Backend data /postgres_data Location for PostgreSQL databases /pgadmin/data Location for pgAdmin 4 data /zilean/app/data Location for Zilean data /plex_debrid/config Location for plex_debrid data /cli_debrid/data Location for cli_debrid data /phalanx_db/data Location for phalanx_db data /decypharr Location for decypharr data /plex Location for Plex Media Server data /mnt/debrid Location for raw debrid files/links and symlinks

/config

If a Zurg config.yml and/or Zurg app is placed here, it will be used to override the default configuration and/or app used at startup.

/mnt/debrid:rshared

The :rshared must be included in order to support mount propagation for rclone to the host when exposing the raw debrid files/links to an external container; e.g., the arrs or a media server.

:rshared is not required when using the default configuration leveraging the internal media server or when not utilizing Decypharr.

Configuration Requirements

All deployment methods rely on a valid and accessible dumb_config.json file for configuring services.

It is strongly recommended to bind-mount a local config directory to persist user data.

Example Volume Mount

dumb:
  image: iampuid0/dumb:latest
  volumes:
    - ./config:/config

For more about configuring services, see the Configuration page.

items.text:
• Service Overview
  • Features

items.title: Deploying DUMB with Docker
items.text:
This guide will walk you through every step, from installing Docker to setting up and running the DUMB container.

Whether you're new to Docker or just need a quick refresher, you'll be up and running in no time.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following:

  • A system running Ubuntu 20.04 or later
  • A non-root user with sudo privileges
  • An active internet connection
  • Basic familiarity with using the terminal

This guide assumes you're installing Docker on a fresh Ubuntu setup. If you're on Windows, refer to the Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL).

items.title: Install Docker
items.text:
1. From Ubuntu, install Docker by pasting the following into the Ubuntu Command Line Interface (CLI); follow the prompts. 
    curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sh get-docker.sh

WSL DETECTED

If you receive the following prompt during the Docker install, then follow the steps here: Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL) 

WSL DETECTED: We recommend using Docker Desktop for Windows.
Please get Docker Desktop from https://www.docker.com/products/docker-desktop/

items.title: Confirm Docker Install
items.text:
1. Enter the following command: 
    docker compose version
  2. If the output is similar to the below, then docker and docker compose were successfully installed: 
    ubuntu@DUMB:~$ docker compose version
Docker Compose version v2.24.2

items.title: Define the Directory Structure
items.text:
If you already have a directory structure you'd like to use, then you can skip this step.

  1. Create a directory for docker in your user directory and change directories to docker. 

    cd ~ && mkdir docker && cd docker

  2. Create the DUMB directories. 

    mkdir -p DUMB/config DUMB/log DUMB/data DUMB/mnt/debrid

items.title: Download and Edit the docker-compose.yml
items.text:
The docker-compose.yml file will need to be edited to include the necessary environment variable values.

  1. Download the latest docker-compose.yml from the GitHub repository with the following: 

    curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/I-am-PUID-0/DUMB/master/docker-compose.yml

  2. Run the following command to update the paths in the docker-compose.yml 

    sed -i "s|/home/username/docker/DUMB|$HOME/docker/DUMB|g" docker-compose.yml

  3. Run the following command to update the docker-compose.yml

timezone

The bellow command defaults to TZ=UTC, update while running the command if desired

read -p "Enter your timezone [UTC]: " TZ && TZ=${TZ:-UTC} && \
sed -i \
  -e "s|TZ=|TZ=$TZ|" \
  -e "s|PUID=|PUID=$(id -u)|" \
  -e "s|PGID=|PGID=$(id -g)|" \
  docker-compose.yml

items.title: Start up the Docker Compose
items.text:
Docker Compose

The following command starts Docker Compose in detached mode, meaning it runs in the background and frees up your terminal.

If you omit the -d flag, Docker Compose will run in the foreground, streaming all container logs directly to your terminal.

This is useful for debugging or monitoring in real time, but you will need to open another terminal to run additional commands while it's running.

  • Pressing Ctrl + C will shut down all running containers.
  • To exit without stopping the container(s), you must start Docker Compose in detached mode using -d.

There is no built-in "detach shortcut" when running in the foreground ‚Äî to keep containers running after exit, always use the below command

sudo docker compose up -d

Example output: 

ubuntu@DUMB:~/docker$ sudo docker compose up -d
[+] Running 1/2
 ‚†ã Network docker_default  Created                                                                                                                                                       1.1s 
  Container DUMB       Started

Once started, the container will run in the background.

items.title: That‚Äôs It!
items.text:
Once deployed, DUMB will initialize and make its services available at their respective ports (e.g., DUMB Frontend at :3005, API at :8000, etc.).

You can now manage DUMB entirely through the DUMB Frontend, or explore the Configuration docs to adjust settings as needed.

items.title: ‚ñ∂ Attach to the Running Container
items.text: sudo docker attach DUMB

items.title: Detach Without Stopping the Container
items.text:
Press Ctrl + P followed by Ctrl + Q.

This sequence sends a signal to Docker to detach from the container while leaving it running in the background.

Use this sequence rather than simply closing the terminal window or using Ctrl + C, as those actions might stop the container.

Ctrl + P + Ctrl + Q

Remember, Ctrl + P + Ctrl + Q must be pressed in quick succession.

You press Ctrl + P first, and while holding Ctrl, press Q.

After this, you will be returned to your host terminal, and the container will continue to run in the background.

items.title: View Docker Container Logs
items.text:
To view the container logs, enter the following:

sudo docker container logs DUMB

Alternatively, use -f to follow the logs in real-time.

You can exit with Ctrl + C (this does not stop the container).

sudo docker logs -f DUMB

items.title: Shutdown Docker Compose
items.text:
sudo docker compose down

Example output: 

ubuntu@DUMB:~/docker$ sudo docker compose down
[+] Running 2/2
 Container DUMB       Removed                                                                                                                                                      10.4s 
 Network docker_default  Removed

items.title: Deploying DUMB with Portainer
items.text: Portainer provides a user-friendly web interface for managing Docker containers and stacks. This guide walks you through deploying Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) using Portainer's stack deployment feature.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before you begin:

  • Docker and Portainer must be installed and running
  • Internet access (to pull the DUMB image)
  • Mounted host directories for persistent data storage

items.title: 1. Log into Portainer
items.text: Navigate to your Portainer instance (e.g., http://localhost:9000, or https://localhost:9443) and log in.

items.title: 2. Navigate to Stacks
items.text: Click on Stacks in the left sidebar.

items.title: 3. Click "Add Stack"
items.text: Click the + Add stack button at the top-right.

items.title: 4. Configure the Stack
items.text:
Enter the following:

  • Name: dumb
  • Build method: Select Web editor
  • Web editor: Paste the DUMB docker-compose content (see below)

Important

The docker-compose.yml file must be updated to include the correct environment variable values and host paths. For example, replace /home/username/docker with the actual path on your system.

items.title: 5. Deploy the Stack
items.text: Click Deploy the stack to launch DUMB.

items.title: That‚Äôs It!
items.text:
Once deployed, DUMB will initialize and make its services available at their respective ports (e.g., DUMB Frontend at :3005, API at :8000, etc.).

You can now manage DUMB entirely through the DUMB Frontend, or explore the Configuration docs to adjust settings as needed.

items.title: Viewing Logs for DUMB
items.text:
Once your stack is deployed, you can view logs for the DUMB container:

  1. Navigate to Containers from the left sidebar.
  2. Click on the DUMB container name.
  3. Go to the Logs tab.
  4. Logs will stream live by default. You can scroll or refresh for updates.

This is helpful for debugging service startup or checking configuration issues.

items.title: Attach to the Container
items.text:
To view live output or run interactive commands:

  1. From the Containers page, click on the DUMB container.
  2. Click the Attach Console button
  3. Choose a shell (e.g., sh, bash, or /venv/bin/python) and click Connect.

Use this for tasks like inspecting running processes, modifying configs, or testing tools inside the container.

items.title: Console Access
items.text:
You can also use the Console option to access the container shell:

  1. From the Containers tab, click on DUMB.
  2. Click the Console tab.
  3. Choose the shell you wish to run.
  4. Click Connect.

Great for quick inspection or administrative tasks inside the container.

items.title: Deploying DUMB on Proxmox (LXC Container)
items.text: This guide will walk you through deploying DUMB inside a lightweight Ubuntu-based LXC container on Proxmox VE.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
• Proxmox VE installed
  • Internet access on the host
  • Basic knowledge of Proxmox shell and web UI

items.title: Create an Ubuntu LXC Container
items.text:
You can automate Ubuntu LXC creation with the following community script:

bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/community-scripts/ProxmoxVE/main/ct/ubuntu.sh)"

This will download and install an Ubuntu container in Proxmox.

items.title: LXC Configuration for Docker + Fuse Support
items.text: To ensure DUMB works correctly inside your LXC container (especially with Docker, rclone, and bind mounts), you‚Äôll need to update both the container config, the Proxmox host, and optionally configure persistence across reboots.

items.title: Update the LXC Config File
items.text:
<CTID> is the container ID.

  1. Stop the container:

    pct stop <CTID>

  2. Edit the container config file:

    nano /etc/pve/lxc/<CTID>.conf

  3. Ensure the following lines are present:

    features: nesting=1
lxc.cgroup2.devices.allow: a
lxc.cgroup2.devices.allow: c 10:229 rwm
lxc.mount.entry: /dev/fuse dev/fuse none bind,create=file
lxc.mount.entry: /mnt/docker-mounts mnt/docker-mounts none bind,create=dir
lxc.apparmor.profile: unconfined

Note

Don't restart the LXC until the below sections have been completed.

items.title: Configure Host Bind Mount
items.text:
1. On the Proxmox host, create the mount target and bind it:

    mkdir -p /mnt/docker-mounts
mount --bind /mnt/docker-mounts /mnt/docker-mounts
mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts

items.title: Make the Mount Persistent (Recommended)
items.text: This ensures the bind mount is restored after reboots.

items.title: Option A: Use /etc/fstab and manually set the mount propagation after reboot
items.text:
1. Open the file:

    nano /etc/fstab

  2. Add this line at the bottom:

    /mnt/docker-mounts /mnt/docker-mounts none bind 0 0

  3. After a reboot, paste the following 

    mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts

items.title: Option B: Automate rshared with systemd (Optional, but recommended)
items.text:
This ensures the bind mount propagation is set after reboots.

To persist the rshared behavior across boots:

  1. Create a new service file:

    nano /etc/systemd/system/mnt-docker-mounts-rshared.service

  2. Paste the following:

    [Unit]
Description=Make /mnt/docker-mounts rshared
After=local-fs.target
RequiresMountsFor=/mnt/docker-mounts

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/mount --make-rshared /mnt/docker-mounts
RemainAfterExit=true

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

  3. Reload systemd and enable the service:

    systemctl daemon-reexec
systemctl enable --now mnt-docker-mounts-rshared.service

items.title: Add and Configure a User inside the LXC (Required)
items.text:
DUMB must be ran as any user other than root

  1. Start/Restart the container:

    pct start <CTID>

    systemctl restart pve-container@<CTID> may need to be used for changes to apply

  2. If not already created in the LXC, add a user (ubuntu) and configure passwordless sudo:

    adduser ubuntu
usermod -aG sudo ubuntu

  3. Enable passwordless sudo (Optional): 

    echo "ubuntu ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL" > /etc/sudoers.d/ubuntu
chmod 440 /etc/sudoers.d/ubuntu

    Tip

    To find the UID and GID (needed for PUID and PGID in your DUMB config): 

    id ubuntu

    Example output: 

    uid=1000(ubuntu) gid=1000(ubuntu)

    Use these values in your dumb_config.json or docker-compose: 

    "puid": 1000,
"pgid": 1000,

items.title: Define the Directory Structure inside the LXC
items.text:
Note

If you already have a directory structure you'd like to use, then you can skip this step.

  1. Switch to the ubuntu user:

    su ubuntu

  2. Create a directory for docker in your user directory and change directories to docker. 

    cd ~ && mkdir docker && cd docker

  3. Create the DUMB directories. 

    mkdir -p DUMB/config DUMB/log DUMB/Zurg/RD DUMB/Riven/data DUMB/Riven/mnt DUMB/PostgreSQL/data DUMB/pgAdmin4/data DUMB/Zilean/data

items.title: Install Docker inside the LXC
items.text:
1. Run the official Docker install script:

    curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o get-docker.sh
sh get-docker.sh

  2. After installing Docker, verify it: 

    docker --version
docker compose version

  3. Add your user to the docker group: 

    sudo groupadd docker
sudo usermod -aG docker $USER

items.title: Install Portainer inside the LXC (Optional)
items.text:
If you want to manage Docker visually via Portainer:

  1. Create the Portainer data volume: 

    docker volume create portainer_data

  2. Start the Portainer container:

    docker run -d \
-p 8000:8000 \
-p 9443:9443 \
--name portainer \
--restart=always \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
-v portainer_data:/data \
portainer/portainer-ce:latest

You can now manage Docker containers via the browser at: https://<ip>:9443

Note

On the first run of Portainer, you need to access the Web UI quickly to create your initial administrator user, which is crucial for accessing and managing your Docker environment.

Tip

If you can't access the UI after the initial setup, ensure the Portainer container is running and that the correct port is open. You might need to restart the container if it timed out.

For more, see the Portainer Deployment Guide.

items.title: Update Docker Bind Mount (Important)
items.text:
When launching DUMB or your media server, make sure the following mount is used:

Replace: 

- /home/username/docker/DUMB/Zurg/mnt:/data:shared

With: 

- /mnt/docker-mounts:/data:rshared

This ensures proper visibility between zurg, rclone, and your media server inside the LXC container.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
Now that Docker (and optionally Portainer) are installed, continue with:

  • Deploy DUMB via Docker Compose
  • Configure your stack with Portainer

items.title: Deploying DUMB on unRAID
items.text: This guide will walk you through deploying Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge (DUMB) on unRAID using the Community Applications plugin and Docker.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
Before proceeding, ensure you have the following:

  • A running unRAID server with Docker enabled.
  • The Community Applications plugin installed.
  • At least one unRAID share for persistent storage (e.g., /mnt/user/appdata/DUMB).
  • An understanding of basic Docker container and volume mapping in unRAID.

Optional but recommended:

  • Installed media server such as Plex, Jellyfin, or Emby.
  • A valid Plex Token (if using Plex integration).

items.title: 1. Install the DUMB Template
items.text:
• Navigate to the Apps tab in unRAID.
  • Search for DUMB and select the Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge template.
  • Click Install.

items.title: 2. Path and Variable Configuration
items.text: Ensure your paths and environment variables are set correctly: - Mount all relevant paths (e.g., /mnt, /config, /cache) to valid unRAID shares. - Set your PUID to 99 and PGID to 100 (used for nobody:users on unRAID). - Set your timezone (TZ) appropriately (e.g., America/New_York).

items.title: 3. Fix Permissions (First-Time Only)
items.text: Docker on unRAID may create directories as root, causing permission issues. Fix this using the following method:

items.title: Terminal Method:
items.text: chown -R 99:100 /mnt/user/appdata/DUMB

items.title: WebUI Method:
items.text:
1. Go to Shares > locate your DUMB share.
  2. Click the + to expand.
  3. Under Owner, set to nobody (user ID 99).

items.title: 4. Start the Container
items.text:
• Click Start in the Docker tab.
  • Open the Logs tab to confirm successful startup.
  • Look for a confirmation message that riven frontend has started.

items.title: Matching Paths in Plex, Jellyfin, Emby
items.text:
Your Media Server (Plex, Jellyfin, or Emby) must have the same paths as DUMB:

  • DUMB mounts:
  • /mnt (contains both Riven and Zurg content)
  • In your media server:
  • Mount /mnt to /mnt as well.
  • Only add the Riven path (e.g., /mnt/movies, /mnt/shows) as libraries.

Do NOT add /data or Zurg‚Äôs full rclone mount as libraries. Use only the Riven symlinked content.

items.title: Example Screenshots
items.text:
• DUMB Docker setup:
  • Plex Docker container setup:
  • Plex UI Library paths:

items.title: Plex Token Setup
items.text:
To enable features like watchlist syncing, you may need your Plex token:

  1. Visit https://plex.tv, login.
  2. Open any item > click the 3 dots > View XML.
  3. At the end of the URL, copy the value after Plex-Token=.

items.title: Advanced Tools
items.text:
To troubleshoot permissions or inspect mounts: 

docker exec -w /mnt/movies dumb ls -Rl
To enter the container interactively: 
docker exec -it dumb sh
Install Midnight Commander (optional): 
apk add mc && mc

items.title: Jellyfin and Emby Notes
items.text:
Both Jellyfin and Emby can work with DUMB:

  • Map /mnt into the containers.
  • Add only the Riven subpaths (/mnt/movies, /mnt/shows) as libraries.

items.title: Troubleshooting
items.text:
• Check logs via Docker tab > select DUMB > Logs.
  • Use docker exec or Midnight Commander to inspect file/folder structure.
  • Common issues:
  • Wrong PUID/PGID
  • Paths not matching between DUMB and your media server
  • Invalid Plex token

items.title: Deploying DUMB on Windows Setup Guide (Docker/WSL)
items.text:
Docker Desktop

Ensure that Docker Desktop is not installed; if so, uninstall and reboot before proceeding.

This guide will walk you through setting up DUMB on a Windows system using a lightweight Docker + WSL2 setup, without relying on Docker Desktop.

items.title: WSL Install
items.text:
1. From the Microsoft Store, install Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

  2. From the Microsoft Store, install Ubuntu 22.04 LTS

  3. Follow the setup to create your Ubuntu username and password

  4. From a Windows Command Prompt, paste the following:

    cd C:\WINDOWS\system32

  5. Then set Ubuntu 22.04 as the default distro:

    wsl --setdefault Ubuntu-22.04

  6. From the Windows app menu, start Ubuntu 22.04, then paste the following inside the terminal:

    Note

    This step is only required if sharing the mount outside of the container - e.g., to another media server, etc. 

    sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade -y
sudo mount --make-rshared /

    Note

    sudo mount --make-rshared / does not persist after reboots. You‚Äôll need to run it each time WSL2 or Windows is restarted.

    Alternatively, see the Ubuntu systemd service guide to automate this at startup.

items.title: Docker Install
items.text:
1. Follow the official Docker Engine install guide for Ubuntu

  2. Once Docker is installed, you can either:

    • Use the standard Docker CLI to create the container
    • Or follow the Docker Deployment or Portainer Deployment guides for predefined setups

items.title: Accessing the Mount on Windows
items.text:
Note

These steps are only required if sharing the mount outside of the container - e.g., to another media server, etc.

  1. From the Ubuntu terminal, open File Explorer in the current directory:

    explorer.exe .

  2. A new File Explorer window will appear ‚Äî you‚Äôre now inside the Ubuntu file system

  3. Navigate to the mount location and copy the full path from the Explorer address bar

  4. In another File Explorer window:

    • Click This PC
    • Right-click in the blank space and select Add a network location

  5. In the popup:

    • Click Next twice
    • Paste the WSL path you copied

  6. Complete the remaining prompts to finalize the mount

items.title: Mirrored Mode Networking
items.text: Starting with Windows 11 22H2, WSL2 supports a new networking mode called mirrored networking, which improves compatibility and unlocks several new features by mirroring Windows' network interfaces into Linux.

items.title: Benefits of Mirrored Networking
items.text:
• Full IPv6 support
  • Access Windows services from WSL using 127.0.0.1
  • Improved VPN support (VPNs work in both Windows and WSL)
  • Multicast compatibility
  • Reach WSL directly from your local LAN

items.title: Enabling Mirrored Mode
items.text:
1. Open (or create) the .wslconfig file in your Windows home directory:

    notepad $env:USERPROFILE\.wslconfig

  2. Add the following section:

    [wsl2]
networkingMode=mirrored

  3. Restart WSL for the changes to take effect:

    wsl --shutdown

    Then restart your distro from the Windows menu or run:

    wsl

items.title: Additional Notes
items.text:
• You can combine this with autoProxy=true if you're using a proxy.
  • This setting applies globally across all WSL2 instances.

items.title: Extra Credit
items.text:
If you want to manage Docker visually via Portainer:

  1. Create the Portainer data volume: 

    docker volume create portainer_data

  2. Start the Portainer container:

    docker run -d \
-p 8000:8000 \
-p 9443:9443 \
--name portainer \
--restart=always \
-v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock \
-v portainer_data:/data \
portainer/portainer-ce:latest

You can now manage Docker containers via the browser at: https://<ip>:9443

Note

On the first run of Portainer, you need to access the Web UI quickly to create your initial administrator user, which is crucial for accessing and managing your Docker environment.

Tip

If you can't access the UI after the initial setup, ensure the Portainer container is running and that the correct port is open. You might need to restart the container if it timed out.

For more, see the Portainer Deployment Guide.

Now you‚Äôre ready to run DUMB inside WSL2 with full Docker support ‚Äî no Docker Desktop required!

items.title: DUMB FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to DUMB.

items.title: Does the DUMB image have the latest version of x
items.text:
The GitHub repo for DUMB use many continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) workflows to ensure proper building, reporting, and updating of the images.

For example, the Check for New Release Tags workflow is automated to run every three hours and check for updates to the various services/projects utilized in DUMB. If an update is found, the Docker Image CI workflow is called to build a new image with the latest services.

items.title: What versions are in the latest DUMB image
items.text:
Similar to the above question, and the answer is usually the latest; however, if there has been a recent release and the Check for New Release Tags workflow has not run yet, then there my be disparity.

To check, click on one of the Docker Image CI jobs to see the Build Summary

Example Build Summary below:

items.title: General FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to DUMB that apply across multiple services or the platform as a whole.

items.title: Will DUMB use a lot of storage space?
items.text:
That depends on how you configure it. Most services (like Zurg and Rclone) operate by streaming content from the debrid service, so very little is permanently stored on your local system ‚Äî unless you're using rclone with VFS caching enabled.

VFS Cache Management

If you're using VFS cache (recommended for Plex), ensure that the cache size is managed appropriately. See the rclone configuration for more.

items.title: Do I need to install every service?
items.text:
No ‚Äî DUMB is modular. You can enable or disable services in dumb_config.json under each service section.

Service Types

Some core services (like riven_backend, cli_debrid, etc.) provide core functionality and have required dependent services (like zurg, rclone, postgres, etc.), but others (like pgadmin) are optional service tools to help you manage your setup.

items.title: Can I run DUMB offline?
items.text:
Internet Required

Most DUMB services interact with external APIs (e.g., Real-Debrid, Plex, Trakt, TMDB, etc.), so internet access is required for normal operation. However, local database tools (e.g., pgAdmin) and UIs may still function offline for inspection.

items.title: What happens when I update DUMB?
items.text:
The image maintained for DUMB is automatically updated when one of the embedded services (like riven_backend, cli_debrid, etc.) have a new release available; thus, reducing the need to update to the latest release inside the container. For more info, see the DUMB FAQ regarding finding what versions are built into the image.

Alternatively, DUMB also includes auto-update functionality for most services. Depending on your configuration (auto_update and auto_update_interval), the system will check for new versions of services like Zurg, Riven, Zilean, etc.

You can configure update frequency and behavior in each service‚Äôs section of dumb_config.json.

items.title: Is DUMB secure?
items.text:
DUMB is intended to run on your local or private server. Most services are, by default, bound to 127.0.0.1 and not exposed publicly unless explicitly configured by exposing ports in the Docker compose or changing the bound address.

Security Considerations

Most of the web-based UIs and APIs lack any form of authentication.

If you're exposing services externally (e.g., via Traefik or NGINX), consider using authentication layers like OAuth2, HTTPS, and firewalls.

items.title: Can I use my own custom version of a service?
items.text: Yes ‚Äî you can point most services to a custom branch or fork by editing the repo_owner, repo_name, branch, or release_version in its config section in dumb_config.json. This is especially useful if you are testing development builds or your own patches.

items.title: Can I back up my DUMB setup?
items.text:
Absolutely. The most important files to back up are:

  • dumb_config.json
  • Any data directories (e.g., /riven/backend/data, /zilean/app/data, /pgadmin/data, postgres_data, plex, etc)

Backup Strategy

Regularly backing these up allows you to quickly restore your environment.

Exclude Mounted Paths

Be sure to exclude any mounted paths (e.g., /mnt/debrid) when backing up. Otherwise, you'll unintentionally download and archive the entire contents of your debrid services, which can be massive and unnecessary.

Don't believe me? Just ask Mr. Krabs.

items.title: Can I monitor the system?
items.text: Yes ‚Äî the DUMB Frontend shows real-time logs, service logs, service status, and allows interactive config management. You can also access logs from the filesystem or via the DUMB API (see API docs).

items.title: What's the difference between using rclone/Zurg mounts vs. symlinks (Riven, CLI Debrid, Decypharr, etc.) in my media server?
items.text:
DUMB supports two methods of exposing content to your media server, each with its own use case:

Direct Mount (Zurg/rclone)Symlinked Mount (Riven/CLI Debrid/Decypharr)

Mounting the WebDAV or remote storage directly using rclone (which often connects to a Zurg instance) gives you full access to all files in your debrid account.

Pros:

  • Access to all debrid content, including content not added by Riven
  • Instant visibility of new files from your debrid service
  • Useful for manual browsing or catching content missed by automation
  • Allows content orchestration with Debrid Media Manager (DMM)
  • Less complexity when sharing mounts across the host or network

Cons:

  • File/folder naming is often inconsistent or messy
  • Can lead to Plex/Emby/Jellyfin misidentification
  • Media scanners may perform poorly due to large, unorganized libraries

Services like Riven, CLI Debrid, or Decypharr create cleanly named symlinks pointing to content in the underlying Zurg/rclone mount (usually in a shared directory like /mnt/debrid/riven).

These symlinks are stored in a separate directory (like /mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks) and represent only curated content that has been identified and processed.

Pros:

  • Only includes content that's been properly scraped and sorted
  • Directory structure and filenames are optimized for media servers
  • More accurate library scans and faster detection
  • Ideal for fully automated Plex/Emby/Jellyfin setups

Cons:

  • Only includes what has been processed ‚Äî not your full debrid library
  • Requires the service to stay running and correctly configured
  • If settings are misconfigured, some content may not appear
  • If the database is lost or reset, all content must be scraped and added again
  • Symlinks add complexity by requiring your media server to share the same exact container paths as defined in DUMB's dumb_config.json ‚Äî e.g., /mnt/debrid must exist exactly the same inside your media server container or on the host when the media server is not containerized

items.title: Host-Based Media Server: Mount Path Consistency
items.text:
If your media server (such as Plex) runs directly on the host (not in Docker), it will access media files using the host's file system. In this setup, any symlinks created inside the DUMB container must resolve correctly on the host. This means the media paths inside the container must exactly match the paths used by the host.

Symlink resolution is based on absolute paths. If those paths don't exist or don't match outside the container, the symlinks will be broken or unusable by the media server.

items.title: Example: Using Riven's Symlink Media Directory
items.text:
Suppose your media is mounted on the host at:

/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid

Since Plex (or another media server) and the DUMB container need to both access this path and resolve symlinks, your Docker bind mount must look like:

/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid:/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid

This differs from the the default /docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid:/mnt/debrid internal path for the container by prepending /docker/DUMB or whatever the host side absolute path is for the /mnt/debrid directory

Then, inside the dumb_config.json, you would also need to make sure you define the updated internal path for symlinks:

"riven_backend": {
  "symlink_library_path": "/docker/DUMB/mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks",
}

This ensures that any symlinks Riven creates will remain valid on the host.

items.title: Simplified Approach Using Standard Paths
items.text:
To simplify configuration and reduce the need to hardcode deep paths, you can instead use standard directory mounts like /mnt.

Docker Compose example:

/mnt/debrid:/mnt/debrid

And then update the configuration:

The below is the default path used in the container when configured through the onboarding process

"riven_backend": {
  "symlink_library_path": "/mnt/debrid/riven_symlinks",
}

Using standardized top-level paths makes your setup more portable and ensures symlinks will resolve correctly regardless of the underlying directory structure.

also review the Default Mount Structure and Mount Propagation sections for additional details!

items.title: pgAdmin FAQ
items.text: Below are common questions and helpful usage tips for working with pgAdmin in DUMB.

items.title: What is pgAdmin used for in DUMB?
items.text:
pgAdmin is a web-based GUI for managing PostgreSQL. In the context of DUMB, it connects to the PostgreSQL instance used by services like Riven and Zilean.

You can use it to:

  • Explore and modify database tables and data
  • Run SQL queries manually using the Query Tool
  • Schedule tasks using pgAgent (optional tool inside pgAdmin)
  • View the System Stats inside PostgreSQL

items.title: Using pgAdmin‚Äôs Query Tool
items.text:
To run manual queries (e.g., inspecting or modifying blacklist entries):

  1. Navigate to the "Databases" list in the left sidebar.
  2. Right-click the riven or zilean database.
  3. Select Query Tool.
  4. Paste your SQL query in the top panel and run it.

items.title: Example: View & Clear Riven's Stream Blacklist
items.text:
SELECT id, media_item_id, stream_id FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";
DELETE FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";

To just view the count:

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "StreamBlacklistRelation";

items.title: Save Queries for Later
items.text: Click Save As in the Query Tool to store frequently used queries as .sql files.

items.title: Drop a Database or Create a Manual Backup in pgAdmin
Drop a Database
items.text:
You can delete a database from within pgAdmin if you no longer need it (e.g., to reset Riven or Zilean).

  1. In the Object Browser, expand the Databases section.
  2. Right-click the target database (e.g., riven or zilean).
  3. Select Delete/Drop.
  4. Confirm when prompted.

Warning

This will permanently remove the database and all its data. Ensure you‚Äôve backed up anything you want to keep before proceeding.

items.title: Manually Create a Database Backup
items.text:
To create a backup of any database using the pgAdmin interface:

  1. In the Object Browser, right-click the desired database.
  2. Choose Backup.

  3. In the dialog:

    • Format: Select Custom to enable full database restore capability.
    • Filename: Save to /pgadmin/data/your_backup_name.backup or .sql.

  4. Ensure Dump Options #1 is configured with:

    • Include CREATE DATABASE statement enabled (for standalone restoration)
    • Only data and Only schema unchecked (you want both schema and data)

  5. Under Dump Options #2, verify or set advanced filters if needed.

  6. Click Backup to start the process.

items.title: .backup vs .sql
items.text:
• .backup (Custom Format)

    • Recommended for complete backups
    • Supports compression, selective restore, and full restore via pgAdmin or pg_restore
    • Not human-readable but ideal for production-grade backups

  • .sql (Plain Format)

    • Outputs all SQL commands as text
    • Human-readable and easy to inspect or modify manually
    • Can be restored via psql, but lacks compression and selective restoration features

For a reliable, restorable snapshot of your database, always choose .backup with Custom format.

For more advanced backup configuration and explanation of options, see the pgAdmin Backup Dialog Documentation.

items.title: ‚è± Optional: Use pgAgent to Schedule Tasks
items.text:
pgAdmin comes with pgAgent, which lets you create recurring jobs.

This is entirely optional and not required to use DUMB.

items.title: Example: Scheduled Backups with pgAgent
items.text:
1. Navigate to pgAgent Jobs under your connected DUMB server.

  2. Right-click ‚Üí Create ‚Üí pgAgent Job

  3. Enter the job name and any comments.

  4. Go to the Steps tab and click the + button to Add row.

  5. Edit the new row to configure a backup step.

  6. Enter a step name, set Kind = Batch, and paste your backup command in the Code tab:

    pg_dump --username=DUMB --dbname=riven --clean --file=/pgadmin/data/riven_backup-`date +%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S`.sql
pg_dump --username=DUMB --dbname=zilean --clean --file=/pgadmin/data/zilean_backup-`date +%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S`.sql

  7. Go to the Schedules tab to define when the backup should run.

  8. On the Repeat tab, set a repeat interval like daily at midnight.

  9. Save your pgAgent job.

Backups are saved in /pgadmin/data by default.

items.title: Plex FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to when using Plex alongside DUMB with services like Zurg and Rclone.

items.title: Recommended Library Settings
items.text: To reduce the risk of excessive API calls to Real-Debrid (which can result in 423 Locked errors or rate limits), the following Plex library settings should be disabled for each media library:

items.title: Library Settings (Per Library):
items.text:
• Video Preview Thumbnails
  • Credits Detection
  • Voice Detection
  • Empty trash automatically after every scan (this can trigger deletions unnecessarily when using symlinked content)

items.title: Global Settings (Settings > Library):
items.text:
• Scan my library automatically
  • Run a partial scan when changes are detected

These settings reduce the number of filesystem scans Plex performs, which can otherwise generate a high number of requests to mounted Real-Debrid content.

items.title: Plex buffers a lot when playing content mounted via rclone
items.text: This is often caused by the lack of caching when streaming large files from cloud-mounted storage.

items.title: Recommended Solution
items.text:
Enable VFS (Virtual File System) cache in your rclone configuration.

When using DUMB, set the following environment variables: 

RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MODE=full
RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MAX_SIZE=100G
RCLONE_VFS_CACHE_MAX_AGE=6h

These flags ensure that: - The full file is cached locally before playback. - Plex can smoothly read data without constant remote fetches.

See rclone docs or refer to rclone Flags via Environment Variables for examples and formatting guidance.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text:
• Zurg FAQ
  • Rclone Configuration

items.title: PostgreSQL FAQ
items.text: Below are common questions and explanations related to PostgreSQL, which is the primary database engine used by DUMB.

items.title: How PostgreSQL is used in DUMB
items.text:
PostgreSQL is used to store persistent data for the following services:

  • Riven Backend ‚Äì stores indexed content, metadata, scraped results, job states, and user settings.
  • Zilean ‚Äì stores hash lookups, metadata cache, and processing history.

Each service has its own database, created automatically when DUMB starts:

Service Database Name Riven riven Zilean zilean pgAdmin (optional) pgadmin

The database storage path is configured using the postgres_data path in dumb_config.json, defaulting to /postgres_data.

items.title: What happens if I delete the database?
items.text:
If the PostgreSQL volume or /postgres_data directory is deleted, all data for Riven and Zilean will be lost.

This includes:

  • Indexed or scraped content in Riven
  • Cached metadata and hashes in Zilean
  • Any custom settings stored in the database

Both services will start fresh and reinitialize their databases upon next launch.

Accidental deletion of postgres_data is not recoverable

Make sure to regularly back up your postgres_data directory if long-term retention is important.

See the pgAdmin service for details on scheduling backups of the PostgreSQL databases.

items.title: Can I reset the database intentionally?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî stopping the stack, deleting the postgres_data directory, and starting again will reset everything.

Alternatively, use pgAdmin 4 (if enabled) to drop individual databases manually.

See the PostgreSQL Useful Commands section.

Alternatively, See the pgAdmin FAQ section.

items.title: What are the default credentials?
items.text:
• Username: DUMB
  • Password: postgres
  • Port: 5432
  • These values can be customized in the postgres section of dumb_config.json.

items.title: Can I connect to PostgreSQL externally?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî by default, PostgreSQL binds to 127.0.0.1. If you want to connect from an external app (like DBeaver or pgAdmin on your host machine), you'll need to:

  1. Change host in the postgres section of dumb_config.json to 0.0.0.0
  2. Add a port binding (e.g., 5432:5432) to your container
  3. Optionally secure with a firewall or password change

items.title: Is it safe to run queries against the databases?
items.text:
Yes ‚Äî but with caution. Direct queries using tools like pgAdmin or psql can be useful for debugging or data inspection, but changes may break app logic unless you know what you're doing.

When in doubt, make a backup first!

items.title: rclone FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to using rclone with DUMB.

items.title: I think I might be rate limited by the debrid service - seeing 423 errors.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_TSP_LIMIT=10 to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: How do I enable rclone filtering to include only specific resolutions?
Example docker-compose to include only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_EXCLUDE=**/**{{(?i)(1080|720|480)}}** to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: Example docker-compose to exclude only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_EXCLUDE=**/**{{(?i)(4k|uhd|2160)}}** to the environment variable section of the compose.

items.title: Example docker-compose to include only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_FILTER_FROM=/config/filter_include_2160.txt to the environment variable section of the compose and add the below content to a filter_include_2160.txt file in the config directory for the container.

items.title: Example docker-compose to exclude only 4k|2160|UHD content.
items.text: Add - RCLONE_FILTER_FROM=/config/filter_exclude_2160.txt to the environment variable section of the compose and the below content to a filter_exclude_2160.txt file in the config directory for the container.

items.title: Error response from daemon: path /your/host/path/mnt is mounted on / but it is not a shared mount.
items.text:
From the host OS, enter sudo mount --make-rshared /

Or if using a NAS device sudo mount --make-rshared /volume1/

If neither of the above resolves the error, ensure that docker is not installed via snap. Install docker via apt.

Note

sudo mount --make-rshared does not persist reboots, so it will need to be run each time WSL2 or Windows is restarted. Alternatively, see the below guide for automatically executing the command on startup for Ubuntu.

items.title: Ubuntu systemd service:
items.text:
To make Ubuntu run a command like sudo mount --make-rshared / on startup, you can use a systemd service unit that executes this command at boot.

Systemd is a system and service manager for Linux operating systems, which allows you to specify custom startup tasks through service units.

Here's how you can do it:

items.title: Create a systemd service file:
items.text:
First, you need to create a new systemd service file. You can do this by creating a file in the /etc/systemd/system directory. Let's call this file make-rshared.service.

Open a terminal and use your favorite text editor to create this file. You'll need sudo privileges to create a file in this directory. For example, using nano:

sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/make-rshared.service

Add the following contents to the service file:

[Unit]
Description=Make root filesystem rshared
After=local-fs.target

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/bin/mount --make-rshared /
RemainAfterExit=yes

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

items.title: Enable and start the service:
items.text:
After saving the file, you need to reload the systemd daemon to recognize your new service and then enable the service to start on boot:

sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable make-rshared.service
To start the service immediately without rebooting, you can use:

sudo systemctl start make-rshared.service

items.title: Verify the service is active:
items.text:
After rebooting or starting the service, you can check its status to ensure it's active and has run successfully:

sudo systemctl status make-rshared.service

items.text: • Rclone Configuration

items.title: Zilean FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to Zilean when used with DUMB.

items.title: Why is Zilean spamming my logs!?!
items.text:
This is normal for a first-time run of Zilean.

Zilean parses all the Debrid Media Manager (DMM) hash lists and saves them into the PostgreSQL database.

Then, it will run a scheduled update to add/remove any new hash content.

Depending on the system, the first-time run can take hours to days.

items.title: Zurg FAQ
items.text: Below are some common questions and solutions related to Zurg when used with DUMB.

items.title: ERROR - rclone w/ RealDebrid subprocess: : IO error: File is temporarily unavailable: 423 Locked
items.text:
This error generally indicates that a rate limit is being enforced by Real-Debrid. It often occurs during media server scans that hit the API too frequently.

To mitigate this: - If you're using Plex, this is commonly caused by automatic scans that trigger repeatedly. - Alternatively, you may also need to impose a transactions (requests) per second limit with rclone.

See the Plex FAQ for more Plex-specific recommendations and details. See the rclone FAQ for more rclone-specific recommendations and details.

items.title: Related Pages
items.text: • Zurg Configuration

items.title: What is DUMB?
items.text: DUMB (Debrid Unlimited Media Bridge) is an all-in-one media management solution designed to streamline the process of finding, downloading, organizing, and streaming media content. It integrates multiple services into a single Docker image, providing automation and efficiency for managing media libraries.

items.title: Key Features
items.text:
• Unified Deployment ‚Äì Combines multiple tools into a single, easy-to-deploy system with onboarding-driven setup.
  • Built-In Media Server Integration ‚Äì Includes Plex Media Server, Jellyfin, and Emby, fully embedded in the container to eliminate mount propagation issues.
  • Automated Content Management ‚Äì Uses Debrid and Usenet services alongside Plex Discover Watchlists, Trakt lists, and Seerr to automate media retrieval.
  • Arr + WebDAV Workflows ‚Äì Supports Sonarr, Radarr, Lidarr, Whisparr, plus WebDAV-driven clients like Decypharr (Debrid) and NzbDAV (Usenet).
  • Integrated Web UI ‚Äì Control and manage services through a simple web-based interface.
  • Modular Design ‚Äì Each service (Riven, Zurg, Zilean, etc.) is independently configurable and upgradable.
  • Advanced Logging & Monitoring ‚Äì View and filter service logs directly from the DUMB Frontend.

items.title: Core Components
items.text: DUMB integrates the following projects to create a seamless media experience:

items.title: Riven
items.text: Riven is one of multiple options responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: CLI Debrid
items.text: CLI Debrid is one of multiple options responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: Decypharr
items.text: Decypharr is a Debrid-focused option responsible for content management, handling search queries, downloading, and organizing media for streaming.

items.title: NzbDAV
items.text: NzbDAV provides an NZB WebDAV gateway and Arr download-client integration for Usenet workflows.

items.title: Prowlarr
items.text: Prowlarr centralizes indexer management and syncs indexers across the Arr stack.

items.title: Arrs (Sonarr/Radarr/Lidarr/Whisparr)
items.text: The Arrs handle TV, movies, music, and adult content automation and organization. During onboarding, selecting Decypharr or NzbDAV can wire Arr instances automatically.

items.title: Zurg
items.text: Zurg acts as the automation engine that interacts with Real-Debrid to fetch media files.

items.title: Zilean
items.text: Zilean enhances content discovery and caching, optimizing the efficiency of media lookups.

items.title: rclone
items.text: rclone manages cloud storage connections and allows mounting remote debrid storage as if it were a local drive.

items.title: Plex Media Server
items.text: Plex is bundled directly inside DUMB, providing internal access to rclone-mounted content without needing to expose paths via external bind mounts.

items.title: Jellyfin & Emby
items.text: Jellyfin and Emby are alternative media servers supported inside the same container.

items.title: PostgreSQL & pgAdmin 4
items.text:
• PostgreSQL serves as the primary database for storing metadata, configurations, and user preferences.
  • pgAdmin 4 provides a web-based database management interface, making it easy to manage PostgreSQL.

items.title: How Does It Work?
items.text:
DUMB simplifies the media management workflow by:

  1. Run Onboarding to select core services and auto-enable required dependencies.
  2. Scan Lists & Requests from Plex, Trakt, and Seerr.
  3. Fetch From Debrid or Usenet providers (Real-Debrid, AllDebrid, etc.).
  4. Route Through Orchestrators (Riven/CLI Debrid) or Arr clients (Decypharr/NzbDAV).
  5. Mount & Organize Content via Zurg + rclone and Arr-managed libraries.
  6. Stream via Plex/Jellyfin/Emby using internal paths and embedded media servers.

items.title: Next Steps
items.text: Explore the Configuration section to understand how to set up and customize DUMB according to your needs.

items.title: Overview
items.text:
DUMB relies on a centralized configuration file, dumb_config.json, to control its services, logging, API settings, and more. This file allows you to customize the behavior of DUMB without modifying the source code.

DUMB also supports environment variables, .env files, and Docker secrets. If the same setting is defined in multiple places, the precedence is as follows:

Configuration Precedence

  1. Environment Variables (highest priority)
  2. .env File
  3. Docker Secrets
  4. dumb_config.json (lowest priority)

items.title: Configuration File Structure
items.text:
Be Careful When Modifying dumb_config.json

While DUMB is highly configurable via dumb_config.json, some changes can cause failures during startup. As such, it is not recommended to make modifications unless you fully understand their impact.

Below is the general structure of dumb_config.json:

{
    "puid": 1000,
    "pgid": 1000,
    "tz": "",
    "dumb": { ... },
    "cli_debrid": { ... },
    "cli_battery": { ... },
    "decypharr": { ... },
    "nzbdav": { ... },
    "emby": { ... },
    "jellyfin": { ... },
    "sonarr": { ... },
    "radarr": { ... },
    "lidarr": { ... },
    "prowlarr": { ... },
    "whisparr": { ... },
    "phalanx_db": { ... },
    "plex": { ... },
    "plex_debrid": { ... },
    "postgres": { ... },
    "pgadmin": { ... },
    "rclone": { ... },
    "riven_backend": { ... },
    "riven_frontend": { ... },
    "zilean": { ... },
    "zurg": { ... }
}

Each section configures a specific service.

Below is a breakdown of some of the sections:

items.title: User & Timezone
items.text:
"puid": 1000,
"pgid": 1000,
"tz": ""
  • puid / pgid ‚Äì Define the user and group IDs for container execution.
  • tz ‚Äì Set the timezone (e.g., America/New_York).

Root User Not Allowed

puid/pgid cannot be set to 0 (root). DUMB requires a non-root user for security reasons.

items.title: Logging Settings
items.text:
Located in dumb: 

"log_level": "INFO",
"log_name": "DUMB",
"log_dir": "/log",
"log_count": 2,
"log_size": "10M",
"color_log": true

  • log_level ‚Äì Set the logging verbosity (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR).
  • log_dir ‚Äì Directory where logs are stored.
  • log_count ‚Äì Number of rotated logs to retain.
  • log_size ‚Äì Maximum log file size before rotation.
  • color_log ‚Äì Enables colored log output.

items.title: Integration Tokens & Credentials
items.text:
Located in the dumb section of dumb_config.json:

"plex_token": "",
"plex_address": "",
"github_token": "",
"github_username": ""

items.title: Plex Integration
items.text:
• plex_token ‚Äì This token is used by Riven backend for interacting with your Plex account. It allows features such as using watchlists and sending library scan requests to the Plex server.
  • plex_address ‚Äì The internal or external URL of your Plex server (e.g., http://127.0.0.1:32400).

These values are used automatically by Riven when setting up the Riven Backend.

items.title: GitHub Integration
items.text:
• github_token ‚Äì Used to increase GitHub API rate limits and unlock access to private/sponsored repositories such as zurg when associated with your GitHub account.
  • github_username ‚Äì (Reserved for future use) Will support additional GitHub-sourced services and contributor personalization.

To create a GitHub token:

  1. Go to GitHub Developer Settings ‚Üí Tokens (Classic)
  2. Click Generate new token (classic)

  3. Set an expiration and enable the following scopes:

    • repo:all
    • write:packages
    • read:packages

  4. Click Generate token and copy the token ‚Äî it will only be shown once

  5. Add the token to your .env file or docker compose with DMB_GITHUB_TOKEN=, or dumb_config.json under "github_token"

items.title: Service Configuration
items.text:
Each DUMB-integrated service is configured within its own section of dumb_config.json.

See the individual service pages for in-depth configuration details:

  • DUMB API
  • DUMB Frontend
  • Decypharr
  • CLI Debrid
  • NzbDAV
  • Plex Media Server
  • Jellyfin
  • Emby
  • Sonarr
  • Radarr
  • Lidarr
  • Prowlarr
  • Whisparr
  • pgAdmin 4
  • PostgreSQL
  • rclone
  • Riven Backend
  • Riven Frontend
  • Zilean
  • Zurg

items.title: core_service (Arr Integration)
items.text:
Some services (notably the Arrs) include a core_service field to tell DUMB which core workflow they should attach to.

Allowed values:

  • "" (blank): no core integration
  • decypharr: route Arr automation through Decypharr
  • nzbdav: route Arr automation through NzbDAV

Examples:

"sonarr": {
  "instances": {
    "Default": {
      "core_service": "decypharr"
    }
  }
}

"radarr": {
  "instances": {
    "Default": {
      "core_service": "nzbdav"
    }
  }
}

items.title: Next Steps
items.text:
1. Review and modify dumb_config.json as needed.
  2. Review the Usage page.
  3. For a deep dive into individual services, see the Services section.

items.title: Running DUMB
items.text:
DUMB automatically starts the services defined in dumb_config.json in the proper order. Each service can also be managed independently using the DUMB Frontend or by directly modifying the configuration.

Onboarding

DUMB is preset to disable all services, other than the API and Frontend on the first startup.

On first launch of the DUMB Frontend, you will be directed to the Onboarding process.

items.title: Automatic Service Start
items.text:
All services with "enabled": true in the config will be started on container launch.

If a service fails to start, check its log file in the /log directory (or wherever log_dir is set).

items.title: Manual Updates
items.text:
Each service can be updated by modifying the configuration file or using the DUMB Frontend.

Updates include:

  • Branch switching
  • Version pinning
  • Auto-update toggling

items.title: Auto-Update
items.text:
Some services support automatic updates.

Enable by setting: 

"auto_update": true,
"auto_update_interval": 24

auto_update_interval is measured in hours.

Services supporting auto-updates:

  • DUMB Frontend
  • Plex Media Server (Future release)
  • Riven Backend and Frontend
  • Decypharr
  • NzbDAV
  • Jellyfin
  • Emby
  • CLI Debrid
  • Plex Debrid
  • Sonarr
  • Radarr
  • Lidarr
  • Prowlarr
  • Whisparr
  • Zilean
  • Zurg

items.title: Shutdown Handling
items.text:
DUMB handles graceful shutdown of all services.

This includes:

  • Stopping running processes
  • Unmounting rclone mounts
  • Syncing configuration states

To allow time for clean shutdowns, use: 

docker-compose:
  stop_grace_period: 60s

items.title: Tips
items.text:
• Always monitor /log/*.log files for troubleshooting or monitor the logs from the DUMB Frontend.
  • Logs can be colored if color_log is enabled in the config.
